text:
15 to 1 Peck Slip, north side, west from Water to Pearl Streets, showing the South Ferry division of the Second and Third Aves. Elevated lines on Pearl Street. O'ertowering the buildings shown, is the pinnacle of the Municipal Building.

May 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

No. 11, the 2½-story building with a white stucco front is reputed to have been standing in 1725, on land, then owned by Johans Hardenbrooke. Adjoining same, is a 4-story tenement, No. 9, at one time the home of former Governor Alfred E. Smith. The 3-story frame structure, number 7, north of the latter, was the home of Dr. Valentine, of Valentine's Manual fame. It is now the junk shop of Frank Carson. According to the New York Sun of October 2, 1937, these buildings may be demolished. See same for further data.
title: Manhattan: Peck Slip - Pearl Street

text:
(1) Ferry Street, west from Pearl, to and including Gold Streets. Shown at the termination of Ferry Street, is No. 87 Gold Street, north of the N.W. corner of Spruce Street.

May 3, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same.

April 3, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Peck Slip, north side, east from but not including Pearl, to and including Front Streets. (Peck Slip is arbitrarily set to run east and west).
June 21, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a closer view of Nos. 5-9 Peck Slip, north side, between Pearl and Water Streets. No. 7 Peck Slip is a frame house.
1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 7,

(3)
The same, as No. 1, showing a closer view of Nos. 13-15 Peck Slip, at and adjoining the N.W. corner of Water Street. The view only shows lower stories of buildings.
February 15, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
